Three lines of Latin letters roughly centred and concentrated in the lower half of the face.
Fairly crudely incised letters, somewhat irregular, with staurogram and use of supralines.
17 May 524 CE, dated by the consulate of Opilio and the second indiction.
Nenci, 1991, Un'iscrizione latina cristiana da Segesta
Michelini, 1999, Reimpiego di iscrizioni a Segesta
Four lines of Greek letters centred on the face of the stone, but with a leftward bias.

Very neatly carved wide, regular letters of a fairly square module, with minimal serifs and all letters of near equal size. Straight bar alpha; epsilon with only slightly shorter middle bar; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes descen half-way; omicron near full size; pi has equal length verticals with slight overhang on both sides of the cross bar; rho has large rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is circular and without over-extended vertical; omega is open and tear-drop shaped.
late second century BCE, or early C1 BCE, following Ampolo and Erdas (previously dated earlier by Nenci) and confirmed by parallel material

2nd century BCE; the honorand is named in ISic001111, which is dated to the 2nd century BCE from its archaeological context
Two texts are incised on the front of the base, one on the main face between the principal mouldings, and a second on the smaller upper section, between the two upper mouldings.
Two lines of large Greek letters preserved across the long face of the rectangular block.
Plain and thinly incised, regular letters with a reasonably wide module. Alpha has straight bar; kappa has full length arms, rho has a large rounded eye; omicron is full size.
The editors adopt a cautious reading, given the plain form of the letters and the limited extent of the text, suggesting C3 BCE - C1 CE, but with a preference for C2-1 BCE.
Statue base in honour of Diodoros Appeiraios, son of Tittelos

Greek text of six lines on the upper part of the front face immediately below the moulding. Lines 1, 3, 4 set against the left margin, lines 2, 5, 6 indented by approx one letter space; the right margin is irregular. Only line 1 fills the entire width completely.

Letters deeply and regularly cut, with minimal terminal serifs only. Alpha with straight bar; beta with equal closed loops; epsilon with shorter middle stroke; theta circular with detached middle stroke; kappa with nearly full length arms; omicron almost full-size; pi with equal length verticals, horizontal slightly over extended; rho with closed medium loop; sigma with horizontal top and bottom, mid-strokes join approx half-way across; phi with small circular loop, vertical extended; omega either closed or slightly open, extended tear-drop in shape. Note that phi is taller than the rest at 35 mm, omega smaller at 25-28 mm.
The archaeological context, parallel material and palaeography, all support a date in the late second or early first century BCE.
Ampolo, 2022, Segesta. Ephebikon e ginnasio. L’iscrizione greca di Diodoros figlio di Tittelos sulla base della statua del padre e il suo significato storico (secondo supplemento epigrafico 2021)

Alpha with broken bar; omicron smaller than other letters.

On palaeographic grounds, datable to the C3 or C2 BCE; but this inscription, together with several others almost certainly belongs in the context of the monumental stoa of the later second century BCE.
